ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much! I gained new stress management techniques, learned how to deeply connect with a psychology paper and ask the tougher questions, also learned how to challenge today's systems that are inequitable and don't allow for everyone to be best served when dealing with stress. I gained more knowledge about individual differences in the development, maintenance, and diminishment of stress across many areas. Learned how to write a policy paper!
We learned broadly what stress is, what causes stress, what are stress' long and short-term implications, and how to cope with stress (among many other facets of stress).
I loved this course and learnt so much about different psychological theories surrounding every aspect of stress and other varying fields
Class discussion skills and vast insights into stress management and the literature
I developed skills in stress management, based in empirical evidence. I furthered honed my ability to engage with scientific literature in a thoughtful, skeptical, yet hopeful way.
Stress management skills
A really comprehensive and interesting look into the psychology literature and topics related to stress and other mental health concerns
How to critically read psychology papers and write reflections
I learned about all aspects of what human stress really is, including neurobiological determinants, outside triggers, etc.

I learned how to listen. I learned how to participate in discussion, how to build a culture of trust and care, all while simultaneously learning the relevant science on thee psychology of stress. I learned a ton.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There are a lot of readings and you have to understand them all in order to write your reaction papers. However, professor Gee listened to feedback well and reduced the number. We spend a lot of time just talking amongst us students, which I liked, and everyone had thoughts that led to debates and further probing of topics.

I thought this course was really great. I sometimes wish the readings were more varied. Though I liked that class was self-guided, I sometimes wish it were a bit more structured. Sometimes I find two hours of uninterrupted discussion difficult to track, so I wished we changed tactics/gears a bit more.

I also wish we devoted more classtime to discussion of interventions. Sometimes it felt as though we were all so deeply on the same page about the material, that we could have devoted our collective passions to creating solutions/brainstorming ideas/debating those ideas. I was sometimes frustrated/immobilized by the same trends we would stumble upon every class.

strengths: lots of amazing class discussion, interesting content, enjoyable and thought provoking assignments, amazing professor !
weaknesses: maybe better readings/ less reading some weeks

The readings can be on the heavy side some weeks but overall the weekly reading reflections help to stay engaged with course materials and thoughtfully contribute to discussions. Professor Gee is extremely knowledgeable, kind, and considerate and is great at facilitating discussions
Prof Gee is INCREDIBLE! This was the best ive taken at Yale. Our class discussions were so engaging and we become like a close group of friends

Professor Gee's penchant for allowing the class discussion to move fluidly in any direction a given students' response chose was a major credit to the success of this course. It allowed the discussion to be far more granular and far more based in "reality" rather than the sometimes too abstract/difficult to understand realm of scientific literature speak. Professor Gee is also a very engaging and thoughtful instructor, whose lessons, points, and relationship with the class left everyone feeling understood, appreciated, and empowered.

The only weakness of the course that I might suggest an improvement for is the initial reading response. I think for many students this response was the most nerve-wracking, mostly because it was our first real grade and our first real "assignment." To go along with the idea of proposals that this class left us all in (which is a state of mind I still find myself responding to situations with), I propose that Professor Gee should make the first discussion paper a "practice grade." Meaning, students are still expected to complete it with the same degree of care, thoughtfulness, and attention to detail, but they don't have to worry about this paper being the grade that will be "dropped" because it may inevitably be lower than all of their other papers. The idea here is to allow students to receive direct feedback on their structure, ideas, content, and general approach from Professor Gee without the worry of their performance negatively impacting their grade. If having a specific number of graded papers is necessary for the core structure of the course, perhaps Professor Gee could consider including an extra paper, maybe a week earlier, or ask students to write a concluding response paper just based more broadly on the conversations they've had throughout the semester.
I found it intimidating to speak in the discussion.
This is a really great class. The reading load is relatively high, but it does end up being worth it.
Wish there were fewer reaction papers
The course was very engaging because of the discussion-based format and it was easy for everyone to jump in and share their ideas.

DYLAN. Dylan Gee is THE professor. She is kind, warm, incredibly rigorous, thorough in her feedback, clear about her expectations, flexible with your needs, excited to see and get to know you. She was truly one of the greatest professors I've had in college; she is a true gem. Low key if she doesn't get tenure.... we riot girlies. We riot. 

In all seriousness: Dylan fostered amazing discussion. Sometimes the coursework did feel like a lot (e.g. weekly reading responses). But she was willing to pair readings down when we asked her to. Furthermore, I felt like her assignments were all genuinely helpful and contributed to my understanding. I sometimes found the jumpstarts unhelpful, but when we mentioned that to her at midterm she immediately changed he approach, in a way that helped immensely. She is SO GOOD. So SO GOOD.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I absolutely would. One of my favorite courses at Yale by far. Very tuned to student-led and student-driven conversations, with Professor Gee stepping in to offer insight and further comprehension of material. You got to develop an actual policy proposal that would have implications at Yale!

I think this is a nice space to discuss important topics, but I also think this course may attract the type of people who don't need this course. If stress is not something you think about much in your daily life, I would encourage you to take this course because I think it might broaden your perspectives.
If you already have a particularly nuanced concept of stress, this course might not enlighten you much. Though, I think Professor Gee is well worth spending the two hours a week with and the final project is a great exercise that's adaptable to your own personal interests.
yes yes yes
YES!! Prof Gee is incredible the material is great! Take it!!!

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Professor Gee is a wonderful instructor to work with and learn from. The structure of the course is also well-suited to facilitating a students' engagement with the course, particularly the stress management skills.
Yes, if they are interested in learning about stress management skills
Absolutely. Dylan is really great, and makes the course absolutely worth it. This is a wonderful senior seminar
Yes because everyone should learn about stress
Yes!!
Yes, Professor Gee is an amazing professor and facilitator of discussions and I really feel like I learned a lot about stress that is applicable to my daily life.

ABSOLUTELY. You will learn a lot from Dylan. She brings a level of humanity to the sciences that I have genuinely never encountered in a classroom. That doesn't mean she's a pushover; quite the contrary. It means she knows we want to learn, AND that we are people with lives influenced by so much more than a grade or a class. She understands stress; that means she understands Yale. This class won't necessarily teach you anything massively eye-opening in terms of science. but it will hold you accountable to thinking about your own stress, and how to dismantle systemic forces that create and engender and perpetuate stress. Do it.
